reviewText: This is another example of a show with potential being canceled too soon. A New York cop is sent to London to wrap up an investigation. He's asked to stay and work with the police in London. What ensues is a hilarious fish out of water comedy with a detective series edge. This really could have been a great series if it only got the chance.
summary: Great Show With Potential, Canceled Too Soon
Title: N/A

reviewText: Not to take away from the great performances by the blonde on blonde cast of Keen Eddie, but the dog is fabulous.  The episode of his modeling career simply had the entire house in tears...we didn't know a dog could smile.  Keen Eddie is a series of misadventures amid the London Scotland Yard dectective bureau with an out of place NYC detective finding his way in spite of the common language. Adding to the comedy of errors are the fabulous London locations and notable British castmates including newbie, Sienna Miller.Mark Valley as Eddie is a cop out of place with Scotland Yard and his sidekick is a nervous nellie when it comes to the NYC styles of dectective work that his American counterpart enjoys.  However, the British humor and staid upper lip contrast to more in your face policework falls short when Eddie encounters the ill-tempered and too thin, Sienna Miller, a college girl who is his room mate.  The bickering is old as it was done to death in Remington Steele and Moonlighting, however, with the inclusion of the dog and cat (symbolic?), the room mates are almost tolerable.Smart writing, fast edits, and swish-pan camera work make this collection of weekly shows one of the wittier series which of course was cancelled after the first season, and only lends to its popularity and credibility that if it's good, its no longer on air.  At least the DVD's are available, this is a keeper.

reviewText: This series which employs erratic, Guy Ritchie-style camera work that was probably dated before the pilot finished airing works mainly thanks to the charms of its stars.  Mark Valley as the lug out of water is very likable and Sienna Miller was plainly destined for bigger things.  The stories are never terribly compelling and the humor can get pretty crass, but still worth watching.
Title: N/A

reviewText: What do you get when you combine excellent writing, acting, directing and production values? Unfortunately, in the case of Keen Eddie, you get an amazing show that was mishandled and prematurely cancelled by the network.  If you enjoyed Snatch or Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels - or even if you are just looking for a first-rate combination of US-Brit action and humor, Keen Eddie fits the bill - and then some.  Although the DVDs had to omit some of the series' original soundtrack, as is common with DVDs when the original music is difficult or impossible to license, the show is still fresh, innovative and miles beyond most of the shows currently on television or available on DVD.  Although we missed the series when it originally aired, my family is now on its third viewing of the Keen Eddie DVDs, and the show holds up nicely to repeated viewings.

reviewText: I must say that those who are downgrading this DVD set because the music has been changed are not doing the series justice. Yes, it's frustrating that we do not have the orginal music, but even with new music this is still one of the best TV shows ever shown in the US. Everyone needs to just let go of their anger over the the new music and look at this series objectively. Two stars? Three stars? What is wrong with you people? With no music at all, this would still be one of the funniest, wittiest, brightest programs to ever make it onto American TV.

reviewText: Here we are yet again, watching a great show cut short by TV execs with itchy trigger fingers.  It's a shame when there are shows with great characters and great stories that aren't allowed to come to fruition.  Keen Eddie was a witty, entertaining, British infused cop show.  Part of what made it unique and cool was the fact that it was set in England.  That's something you never see on American network television, which is why I turn to BBC America regularly.Keen Eddie is full of colorful and interesting characters played by perfectly cast actors.  Mark Valley as the title character is completely comfortable in the role and has great chemistry with the entire supporting cast.  And I will always be indebted to this show for introducing me to the lovely and talented Sienna Miller (whom I'm now obsessed with) playing Eddie's roommate, Fiona.  The budding love story between Eddie and Fiona was the glue the held the entire episode run together.  Which is why I am irate that this got cancelled before that story could be properly fleshed out (and why this set only gets 4 stars...it's incomplete).Keen Eddie was a show that had everything, a great blend of drama and comedy.  Thankfully we have this DVD set to remind us of why we hate FOX.
Title: N/A

reviewText: It's an excellent cop comedy set in London. Cheeky and fairly daring for its time. The best episodes are the funny ones. Some of them are more focused on the plot and while okay, are not the best. The transition between scenes is done with audio and visual gimmicks that seem dated to me and a bit annoying. Have almost finished the set. My wife and I have been watching 1 or 2 episodes every Saturday night and quite enjoying them.

reviewText: 4.5 starsFound this at the library and enjoyed it a lot. It's both intelligently funny and very well-directed, and all the actors are good and often excellent (Valley). There is little wasted time; the quick cuts and superfast flash-forwards make the viewer pay attention, and that attention is well-rewarded. Creator JH Wyman is clearly a big Guy Ritchie fan, as the cuts and pace are extremely reminiscent of his style; if you loved Lock Stock and Snatch you'll love this too is my guess.By far my favorite episode is Horse Heir, which is as funny as any tv episode I've seen since the best of Arrested Development or Eastbound And Down. That one alone is worth checking this series out for; it's better than most comedy movies these days.The rest are hit and miss, mostly hit. There are plenty of nice themes running through this sadly brief series, my favorite being Eddie's hallucinations of Moneypenny's lust for him. Some of those are flat out classic. His tension with his flatmate is also often very funny, especially if you've ever suffered an insufferable roommate.But imagine my surprise upon reading all these reviews lamenting the loss of the original music (which may have been either greed from the studio, or lack of foresight in buying the rights to both tv and dvd, which is not uncommon, moreso if the show's future is uncertain; Malcolm In The Middle saw a similar fate). I'd LOVE to see the shows again with it, especially with the Specials and Madness and other great ska groups providing the tunes. It does suck that it's gone, but the good news is that the show was very enjoyable without it as well. Kinda glad I never saw this on tv, so I don't know what I'm missing.Sidenote: the theme is from the song Mastermind by Daniel Ash, of Bauhaus and Love And Rockets fame, and while it's a good one, I kept thinking I'd heard it before, especially the Link Wray-ish guitar tone. Finally I realized it's a lift, of both sound and melody, of parts of Robert Palmer's "Johnny and Mary", with a House beat. Check it out and see what you think. I rather like Ash's background music during the show; it may not be as fitting as the original pop tunes, but it certainly has its moments.All in all, Keen Eddie is very good humor, and a little too smart for the average American tv viewer, just like AD and Malcolm, both cancelled far too soon. And make sure to catch Horse Heir...it is truly hilarious.PS And looking around online I found various folks pointing out that this dvd set is in the wrong running order, which I wondered about due to strange shifts in character history (and matchbooks!) while watching it in the dvd sequence. Apparently the proper order is as follows; watch the shows in this sequence and you're bound to have a more logical viewing experience:1, 2, 9, 12, 6, 10, 7, 11, 8, 5, 4, 3, 13Enjoy.
summary: Guy Ritchie meets Kojak! [Review includes proper episode order] Very smart, funny show...would be nice to have the orginal music

reviewText: Screwed up episode order?- Not unheard of.  Warner Home Video did the same with the "Crusade" DVD set.  That's in TNT's moronic airing order.Absence of original music?- How much extra could it have cost for a 13 episode disc set WITH the original music?  Come on suits, WISE UP!The reason for both of these problems is that accountants/MBAs are in charge, and no amount of profit is EVER enough.  The execs don't understand what people want, and WILL PAY FOR.  Sad.  I hope they do a correct set in the future, but I REALLY doubt it.  They'll probably learn the WRONG lesson if this DVD set suffers low sales, and think that people just don't like the show.  Good grief, if there's a way to screw up, suits will find it, AND usually on the first try.5 stars for the show, and 2 stars for this DVD set.Here's hoping that same thing isn't done if Warner Home Video ever decides to release "Brimstone" on DVD (another excellent 13 episode set).  NO SUBSTITUTIONS IN PLACE OF THE ORIGINAL MUSIC!  Got that, suits?
summary: LOVE the Show.  Disappointed in DVD Set.

reviewText: I did not watch this show when it was actually on tv, but I did notice it.  I recently decided to give it a go and have very much enjoyed it.  All the main characters are very entertaining and the guest spots are wonderful.  It is a comedy not a cop drama so the cases are more farfetched then nailbiting.  I feel this is more a plus then a minus.  A classic fish out of water tale with a twist as Eddie seems to be doing quite well other then not understanding british people very well.  The cinematography has a Guy Richie feel to it, which is slightly offputting in a tv show, but in the end good.  Keen Eddie is worth a watch and a good add to your DVD collection.
summary: "How do you like me so Far?"

reviewText: Unlike many of the reviewers here, I never saw the show when it came on in prime-time (and therefore don't know anything about the altered soundtrack). But my wife and I found it to be a very entertaining show and are very sorry that there is only one season. The Eddie character is very appealing - not a clown or an oaf or a boor (even though he tries to be sometimes), like a lot of TV cops, particularly those in comedies like this one. This show obviously had a team of quality writers.Even the somewhat silly (and now dated) camera work is not the turn-off that we thought it would be at first. One gets used to it.I don't find many comedies funny. This one was. Highly recommended.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This was an inspired cop/action/comedy show that premiered on the Fox network in the summer of '03. It quickly became a critical favourite, but it was cancelled due to low ratings and the stupid Fox network shuffling it around and not giving it enough exposure.Mark Valley plays Det. Eddie Arlette, a New York City cop sent to London, England to correct a botched drug bust. The flat he was supposed to be renting is still occupied by the owner's daughter, Fiona Bickerton. Fiona adamantly refuses to let Eddie stay and pretty much dislikes him from the first moment. However, she must let Eddie stay because her mother -- the owner -- is still under the impression that Fiona is at university and Fiona has failed to mention that she has dropped out of school. As soon as Eddie's case is solved, he is offered a position within Scotland Yard. Eddie's new associates include:* Inspector Monty Pippin, his sex-obsessed but stylish and well-dressed partner.* Superintendant Nathaniel Johnson, his humourless superior who is "not sure he likes Eddie but he likes results."* Carol Ross, Nathaniel's secretary who appears quiet but wields a secret sexy power over Eddie.* And of course, Pete. Eddie's tough dog who enjoys biting Eddie's hands, menacing strangers, and shagging Fiona's cat.This show was repeated on Bravo earlier this year, along with 6 episodes that had been previously unaired on Fox. All episodes should be available on this DVD set.The show contains a lively and diverse soundtrack of techno, rock, rap, etc. Flashbacks, flights of fancy, fast-paced camera movements are part of what makes this show interesting and entertaining. Eddie's interactions with Fiona, Pippin and especially Carol are what makes this show enjoyable. Fiona resents having him live with her; they both hate each other, but you can tell they've secretly become fond of each other. Pippin is an unrepentent skirt-chaser; Eddie's concern for how his lifestyle might get him into trouble is sweet, but the two respect each other. And Carol... No, I won't spoil anything; you have to watch it. ;-)I strongly recommend this show.

reviewText: This is one of the quirkiest, funniest shows of recent years. And like all good shows (Dead Like Me, Firefly, Family Guy, etc.) It got cancelled before it could develop a massmarket audience.I don't remember the music, like so many are complaining about, though I do feel that something is missing from the box set. Perhaps that's it. Perhaps it's the lack of bonuses. Nevertheless, this show is so much better than almost anything on TV right now. I watched  some of this set last night and laughed my butt off. Mark Valley is just hilarious, the writing is great, the actors are all top notch, and Pete the dog is hysterical. In a perfect world, this would be given a sceond chance on the networks. Alas...

reviewText: Okay, you've read review after review griping about the altered soundtrack, the out-of-order arrangement, and the lack of any bonus features.  I'm not gonna argue.But frankly, I just don't care.  I saw exactly one episode on TV, and it was enough to make me lunge for the DVD release.  When a show's this much fun, I'll take what I can get, bare bones or no.C'mon, anything that includes the likes of Sticky Fingers, the Lady of the Lift, "a blood feud!", an underground boxer singing "Always Look On the Bright Side Of Life", the AMAY-AY-AYZING Larry Dunn, and a forty-year-old filthy slut who'll do anything (with a HUMAN!) is still better than a sharp stick in the eye, no matter what savaging it's taken from the lawyers who rule the earth.Yeah, I'd like to see a copy that has the original versions, plus outtakes, etc.  But if the watered down 'Keen Eddie' is all I get, I'm still happy.  This puppy is a gift from God -- or, in Pete's case, a hound from Hell.Loo!
summary: How do you like me so far?
Title: N/A

reviewText: I caught a few episodes when this show was on TV, maybe Bravo?  And they were fun to watch.  The format was a little corny in that every episode had a few themes, Mrs. Moneypenny, matchbooks, etc... but at the same time, it works for it.  So when I saw it was available on DVD I wanted to buy it to see the other episodes I never caught.  I wasn't disappointed.  It's a crime series about a detective that is still fun.  This combination is pretty hard to find.  That may be the best part of the series - Eddie's partner's social life, the ongoing war between Eddie and Fiona, and the war of words with his boss.I see some other reviews bash the series because of music or the lack thereof, and honestly I don't remember what music was on the original TV series and frankly, didn't even notice music or a lack of music when I watched the DVDs.  In my mind, the nusic is a non issue.
summary: I wan't a rabid fan on TV and don't remember the music, but this is an entertaining series
Title: N/A

reviewText: The characters in this series are believable and get on well despite their beginning.  I enjoyed each episode as I fell in love with the characters and was very sad to see the series end.  My husband liked the series as well - Sienna Miller & Mark Valley are eye candy but the characters are not just about that.  They are a breath of fresh air compared to other TV shows.  Their living arrangement is odd but it worked.  Since this series ended Mark Valley has starred in several U.S. TV shows which never seem to stay on the air and I don't know why; he is a good actor and has a lot of charisma.  He starred in "Human Target" last year which was cancelled and is now on "Body Of Proof" which I hope will last many seasons but the main character Dana Delaney is a stiff, uptight, unbelievable & bitchy character that Mark Valley has to deal with which can be very irritating.  She overplays her role and she may be the downfall of the series NOT Mark.  I recommend this funny series "Keen Eddie"  highly.
summary: A cute series & sad it was cancelled
Title: N/A

reviewText: I looked forward every week to &quot;Keen Eddie&quot; when it was originally on. Then the network started fiddling with it's time slot, you weren't sure whether it would show up at all and then it went on &quot;hiatus&quot; before they cancelled it outright. It was a disgrace. This show was well written, well acted and had quality production values. In short, it was too good. Maybe if it had been another mindless dribble reality show???!!!! Egad!! The network didn't give it a chance. I am, however, deeply grateful that it is being issued on DVD. Too often a good showed that died an early death disappears without a trace. At least now, when we want to enjoy some wit, we can go back to &quot;Keen Eddie&quot;.
summary: THIS SHOW WAS TOO GOOD FOR IT'S OWN GOOD
